sen.j: 中央交渉会（ちゅうおうこうしょうかい）とは、明治時代に存在した院内会派（1892年4月23日－1893年3月1日）。
sen.e: The Central Negotiation Committee is parliamentary group (April 23, 1892 - March 1, 1893) during Meiji Period.
The Central Negotiation Committee is parliamentary group (April 23, 1892 - March 1, 1893) during Meiji Period.
The Central Negotiation Committee is parliamentary group (April 23, 1892 - March 1, 1893) during Meiji Period.

sen.j: 一般には中央交渉部（ちゅうおうこうしょうぶ）という名称で知られているが、これは本部が置かれた建物名に由来する通称であり、当時の議会の資料には「中央交渉会」と記述されている。
sen.e: It is known as the Central Negotiation Department in general, however, this is a common name from a name of building in which the head office was located, and it is described as 'the Central Negotiation Committee' in the parliamentary documents of that time.

It is known as the Central Negotiation Department in general, however, this is a common name from a name of building in which the head office was located, and it is described as 'the Central Negotiation Committee' in the parliamentary documents of that time.

It is known as the Central Negotiation Department in general, however, this is a common name from a name of building in which the head office was located, and it is described as 'the Central Negotiation Committee' in the parliamentary documents of that time.

sen.j: 大成会を中心とした政府（第1次松方内閣）支持の政党・会派に属する95名が結成した。
sen.e: It was formed by 95 people who belonged to political parties ・ parliamentary groups headed by the Taisei-kai Group which supported the government (the 1st Matsukata cabinet).
sen.cmt: 大成会： the Taisei-kai Group と訳しました。
sen.e: It was formed by 95 people who belonged to political parties ・ parliamentary groups headed by the Taisei-kai Group which supported the government (the 1st Matsukata cabinet).
It was formed by 95 people who belonged to political parties ・ parliamentary groups headed by the Taisei-kai Group which supported the government (the 1st Matsukata cabinet).

sen.j: 古荘嘉門・太田実・津田真道・井上角五郎・末松謙澄・佐々友房・曾禰荒助らが所属する。
sen.e: Kamon FURUSHO, Minoru Ota, Mamichi TSUDA, Kakugoro INOUE, Kencho SUEMATSU, Tomofusa SASSA, and Arasuke SONE were members of the committee.
sen.cmt: 津田直道： Mamichi TSUDA と読みました。
sen.e: Kamon FURUSHO, Minoru Ota, Mamichi TSUDA, Kakugoro INOUE, Kencho SUEMATSU, Tomofusa SASSA, and Arasuke SONE were members of the committee.
Kamon FURUSHO, Minoru Ota, Mamichi TSUDA, Kakugoro INOUE, Kencho SUEMATSU, Tomofusa SASSA, and Arasuke SONE were members of the committee.

sen.j: ところが、中央交渉会の政党化を図る古荘・佐々・曾根らとこれに反対する井上・末松らが対立した。
sen.e: However, a conflict was created between a group formed by Furusho, Sassa, Sone, etc. who tried to get the Central Negotiation Committee into a political party and a group formed by Inoue, Suematsu, etc. who were against the idea.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, a conflict was created between a group formed by Furusho, Sassa, Sone, etc. who tried to get the Central Negotiation Committee into a political party and a group formed by Inoue, Suematsu, etc. who were against the idea.

However, a conflict was created between a group formed by Furusho, Sassa, Sone, etc. who tried to get the Central Negotiation Committee into a political party and a group formed by Inoue, Suematsu, etc. who were against the idea.

sen.j: 結成2ヶ月後の6月22日に古荘らが西郷従道・品川弥二郎を盟主として国民協会_(日本)が結成すると、同協会への合流を巡って分裂状態に陥り離脱者が続出する。
sen.e: On June 22, when two months had passed since the formation of the committee, Furusho and other people formed Kokumin Kyokai (National Association) (Japan) with Tsugumichi SAIGO and Yajiro SHINAGAWA as the leaders, and this tore the committee apart in terms of participation in the association and caused steady stream of defections from the committee.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On June 22, when two months had passed since the formation of the committee, Furusho and other people formed Kokumin Kyokai (National Association) (Japan) with Tsugumichi SAIGO and Yajiro SHINAGAWA as the leaders, and this tore the committee apart in the dispute on whether their joining the association or not and caused steady stream of defections from the committee.
sen.cmt: 同協会への合流を巡って in terms of participation in the association → in the dispute on whether their joining the association or not
sen.e: On June 22, when two months had passed since the formation of the committee, Furusho and other people formed Kokumin Kyokai (National Association) (Japan) with Tsugumichi SAIGO and Yajiro SHINAGAWA as the leaders, and this tore the committee apart in the dispute on whether their joining the association or not and caused steady stream of defections from the committee.

sen.j: その一方で国民協会は独自の院内会派を結成しなかったために、国民協会所属のまま会派だけは中央交渉会に籍をおく議員が存在するなど複雑な状態となった。
sen.e: On the other hand, there were some councilors who belonged to Kokumin Kyokai while remaining to be members of the Central Negotiation Committee as a parliamentary group since Kokumin Kyokai didn't organize their own parliamentary group, and situation became very confusing.

On the other hand, there were some councilors who belonged to Kokumin Kyokai while remaining to be members of the Central Negotiation Committee as a parliamentary group since Kokumin Kyokai didn't organize their own parliamentary group, and situation became very confusing.

On the other hand, there were some councilors who belonged to Kokumin Kyokai while remaining to be members of the Central Negotiation Committee as a parliamentary group since Kokumin Kyokai didn't organize their own parliamentary group, and situation became very confusing.

sen.j: 後に国民協会が院内会派・議院倶楽部を設立するとほとんどが移籍してしまい、他の政党・会派に移籍する者も出た。
sen.e: When Kokumin Kyokai established a parliamentary group ・ the Councilor Society later, most of them transferred their registration, and some even transferred to other political parties ・ groups.
When Kokumin Kyokai established a parliamentary group ・ the Councilor Society later, most of them transferred their registration, and some even transferred to other political parties ・ groups.
When Kokumin Kyokai established a parliamentary group ・ the Councilor Society later, most of them transferred their registration, and some even transferred to other political parties ・ groups.

sen.j: このため、翌年にはわずか11名にまで減少してしまい、路線対立から第4議会終了と同時に残った全議員が離脱したために自然消滅した。
sen.e: Because of this, the number of members of the committee decreased to only 11 next year, and all the remaining councilors after the conflict seceded from it at the same time as when the fourth parliament was shut, and the committee disappeared naturally.

Because of this, the number of members of the committee decreased to only 11 next year, and all the remaining councilors after the conflict seceded from it at the same time as when the fourth parliament was shut, and the committee disappeared naturally.

Because of this, the number of members of the committee decreased to only 11 next year, and all the remaining councilors after the conflict seceded from it at the same time as when the fourth parliament was shut, and the committee disappeared naturally.
